div.head: ❧ By the King.
¶ A Proclamation for the better execution of the Office of His Maiesties Exchanger, and Reformation of sundry Abuses and Fraudes practised vpon his Maiesties Coynes.
div.p: WHereas the Exchange of all manner of Gold and Siluer currant in moneys, or otherwise, as the buying, selling, and exchanging of all manner of Bullion in Species of Forreigne Coynes, Billets, Ingots, or other pieces of Gold or Siluer fine, refined or allayed howsoeuer, being fit for Our Mint, hath euer been, and ought to be Our sole, and appropriate right, as part of Our Prerogatiue Royall, and ancient Reuenew, wherein none of Our Subiects, of what Trade, Mystery, or quality soeuer, ought at all, without Our speciall Licence, to intermeddle, the same being prohibited by diuers Acts of Parliament, & Proclamatiōs both ancient & moderne, heretofore made & published in that behalte: And where as Our Seife, and diuers Our Royal Predecessours, haue, for some time now past, tolerated an indifferent, and promiscuous kinde of liberty to all, but especially to some of the Mystery & Trade of Goldsmiths within Our Citie of London, & elsewhere within Our Dominions, not onely to make the said Exchanges, but to buy and sell all maner of Bullion of Gold & Siluer; and from thence some of them haue growen vnto that licenciousnesse, that they haue for diuers yeeres presumed for their priuate lucre and gaine, and dayly doe presume to sort and weigh all sorts of Moneys currant within Our Realme, to the end to cull out the old and new Moneys, which either by not wearing, or by any other accident, are weightier then the rest; which weightiest and best Moneys, haue not onely been molten downe for the making of Place, Vessell, and other Manufacturies, but euen traded and sold to Merchants, Strangers, and others, who haue transported the same, whereby the consumption of Our Coynes hath been greatly occasioned, not onely to the scarcitie of currant Moneys, especially of siluer Coyne, but also to the great deprauation, and enfeebling of the remainder of Our Siluer moneys, not exported or consumed by the abuses and practises aforesaid, and to the raysing of the Siluer euen of Our owne Moneys to a Rate and Price aboue Our Mint, and aboue what they are truely currant for: By reason whereof no Siluer can bee brought thither, but to the losse of such as bring the same, contrary to the Lawes and policie of Our Realme, and of diuers Actes of Parliament, and late Proclamations in that case prouided and published; The longer permission of all which, would not onely redound to the impeachment of Our Prerogatiue Royall, but doth directly tend to the impouerishment and destruction of Our Realmes.

Wherefore, Wee vpon these, & diuers other weightie considerations, with the Aduice and consent of Our Priuy Counsel, resoluing, not onely to proceede to an entire and perfect reformation of the aboue mentioned, and other such like abuses, by the diligence and industry of such, to whose tare and vigilancie Wee shall commit the same; but also to resume Our said right, and to commit the trust and exercise thereof to such as shall duely administer the same to Our profit, and the good of Our Realme, haue to that purpose, by Our Letters Patents, constituted and appointed Our right trusty and right welbeloued Cousin and Counsellour, Henry Earle of Holland, to haue the Office of Our Changes, Exchanges, and Outchanges wheresoeuer, within Our Realmes of England and Ireland, and Dommion of Wales, To exercise the same by himselfe, or such sufficient deputies as he will answere for. And therefore, to the end that hee and they may the better performe
that trust which Wee haue committed vnto him, without the intermedling or disturbance of any other person whatsoeuer, Our expresse will and pleasure is, And Wee doe hereby straitly charge and command, That no Goldsmith, or other person or persons, of what Trade, Mystery, or quality soeuer, other then the said Henry, Earle of Holland, his Deputies, or Assignes, their Fartors and seruants, within three miles of Our Citie of London, from and after the foure and twentieth day of Iune next comming, or in any other place of this Our Realme of England, and Dominion of Wales, or any of them, from and after the nine and twentieth day of September then next ensuing, presume, or doe change, exchange, or buy, or broke, sollicite, or driue the changing, exchanging, selling or buying of any manner of Bullion in any Species of Forreigne Coyne, or in Billets. Ingots, or other pieces, or Masse of Gold or Siluer whatsoeuer, fine, refined or allayed, or of what other nature or qualitie soeuer: And that no person, or persons whatsoeuer, other then as aforesaid, and respectiuely after the times aforesaid presume, or doe giue, take, or receiue, for, by reason, or vpon the changing or exchanging of any the now currant Coynes, or which hereafter shalbe made & declared the currant Moneys of this Our Realme of England, & Dominion of Wales, for other the currant Moneys of the same, by way of payment, computation, reward, or thing for telling, or otherwise howsoeuer, any summe or summes of Money whatsoeuer, aboue, or more then the said currant Coynes so exchanged, be, or shalbe currant for. And for the better reformation of the abuses aboue mentioned, and others of such like nature, concerning, befalling, or practised vpon Our Coynes, or Bullion, or other Manufacturies of Gold or Siluer, Wee do hereby declare and publish Our Royall will and pleasure, which Wee command to bee strictly obserued in all things, that all persons whatsoeuer, doe effectually and respectiuely obserue, fulfill, and keepe the Articles and Ordinances hereunto annexed, as they will answere the contrary thereof at their vtter most perils.

And further, Wee doe by these presents will and require all and singuler Maiors, Sheriffes, Iustices of Peace, Bayliffes, Constables, Headboroughs, Customers, Comptrollers, Searchers, Wayters, and all other Our Officers, and ministers whatsoeuer, That they, and euery of them, in their seueral places and Offices be diligent, and attendant in the execution of this Our Proclamation, and the said Articies, and Ordinances, aswell in any Search for discouery of any act, or acts to be committed contrary to the intent of these presents, as otherwise in the doing and executing of any matter or thing needefull, or expedient for the accomplishment of this Our Royall Commaund.

div.head: Articles, which, by vertue of Our Proclamation hereunto annexed, Wee will and commaund shall bee duely obserued.
div.p: INprimis, Wee doe expressely will and command, according to a Proclamation, dated the eleuenth day of Iune, in the twentieth yeere of the reigne of Our Royal Father King Iames of blessed memorie, That no person or persons whatsoeuer, doe at any time hereafter, without Our speciall Licence in that behalfe, transport, carry, or conuay, nor attempt or endeuour to transport, carry or conuay out of this Realme any Gold or Siluer, either in coyne, plate, vessels, Iewels, Goldsmiths worke, Bullion, or other Masse, or otherwise howsoeuer: And further, That no person or persons whatsoeuer, doe ayde, assist, counsell, or any wise partake or consent with any other person or persons, purposing or attempting to transport, carry, or conuey out of this Realme any Golde or Siluer in any Species or kinde, as aforesaid, either by gathering or getting together such Golde or Siluer, or by packing vp the same fit for transportation, or conueying the same to, or towards any Port, Hauen, or other place of exportation, or by any other way, meanes, or colour whatsoeuer; And that all and singuler Goldsmiths, Merchants, and their Factors, Masters of Ships, Mariners, Passengers, and all other persons whatsoeuer, that shall haue any notice of Golde or Siluer in Coyne, Iewels, Bullion, Plate or Vessell, or otherwise howsoeuer, which hath bene already exported within the space of two yeeres last past, or shall bee hereafter exported or shipped for exportation, or shall bee gathered and gotten together by Change, Culling, or otherwise, with intention to export, or put into the hands of them which would export it, that they forthwith reueale the same to our Treasurer of England, the Lord President of Our Priuy Counsel, the Vnder-Treasurer of Our Exchequer, or the Warden of the Cinque-ports, or his Deputie, or to Our Attorney generall, or some other of Our learned Counsell, for which discouery, they shall haue and receiue in reward the one halfe of the sayd Gold or Siluer, or of the value thereof, being seized or recouered to Our vse; and on the other part, if they shall not discouer the same, as aforesayd, they shall incurre and receiue such condigne punishment, as by the Lawes of this Our Realme, or by Our prerogatiue Royall may bee inflicted vpon them.

Item, We will and command, that the Statutes and branches of Statutes hereafter particularly expressed, be duely put in execution (that is to say) the Statutes made at Yorke, in the ninth yeere of the reigne of King Edward the third, the sixth, ninth, and tenth Chapters, whereby it is prouided That from thenceforth, the Mayors and Bailiffes in euery Port where Merchants, and ships should be, should take an oath of the Masters, and Merchauts of ships, going, and comming againe, that they should doe no fraud against the prouision of that Law, in any point, and that good and strait search should be made in all places, vpon the Sea coasts, in Hauens, and eiswhere, where any arriual should be, by good, and lawfull men thereto sworne, that in the Kings name, they should make diligent search, that no man of what estate or degree soeuer, should carry out of this Realme, sterling money, siluer or plate, nor vessell of gold or siluer, withour the Kings licence, and that the Searchers should haue the fourth part for their labour, of as much as they should finde so forfeited, and to loose all his goods; if he dispence with any man, and be thereof attaint, as by the same Statute (amongst other things) more fully doeth appeare: And one other Statute, made in the second yeere, of the raigne of king Henry the fourth the fifth chapter, whereby the King did ordaine, & establish, That from thenceforth, if any searcher of the King might finde golde, or siluer in Coyne, or in Masse, in the keeping of any that should bee passing, or vpon his passage, in any ship, or vessel, for to goe out of any port, hauen, or creeke of the Realme, without the Kings speciall licence, that gold, or siluer, should be forfeited to the King (sauing his reasonable expences) as by the same Statute, it doth and may more at large appeare.

And We doe especially charge and command, that the Maiors, and Bayliffes in euery Port, where Merchants, and ships shalbe, and all such to whom the same shall, or may in any wise appertaine, do from heuceforth with speciall careand vigilancy, not only take the oath of all Masters of ships, and Merchants, according to the true meaning of the sath statute, made in the ninth yeere of king Edward the third, but also take an oath of all such Masters, and Merchants of ships, going and comming, as aforesaid, that they haue not transported or conueyed out of this Realme, any gold, orsiluer, (contrary to the true intent of the said Proclamation (giuen the eleuenth day of Iune, in the twentieth yeere of the reigne of our sayd Royall father before recited) at any time or times since they, or any of them, respectiuely tooke, or had notice or knowledge, of Our prohibition thereof, by the first Article before contained.

Item, Wee will and command, That no Goldsmith, Finer, or Parter, or other person whatsoeuer, of what Mystery, Trade, or quality soeuer hee be, presume, enterprize, or doe melt, or cause to be molten, any gold or siluer Coynes, which now are, or hereafter shalbe the currant moneys of any Our Realmes or Dominions, either to make Plate, Vessell, or for any other Manufacture, or vse whatsoeuer, norpresume, or doe cull, or sort from the rest, any the weightier Moneys, to the intent to conuey the same out of this Realme, or to melt, or otherwise to alter it from Coyne, contrary to diuers Lawes and Proclamations published in that behalfe.

Item, that no person or persons, other then Our Changer, or Exchanger, for the time being, his Deputies, or Assignes, their Factors or Seruants, do receiue, or take by way of payment, exchange or computation, or other way whatsoeuer, directly or indirectly, for any Species of Forreigne Coine, or other Gold or Siluer, in Pieces, or Masse, fined, refined or allayed, aboue, or more then the Rates or Prices which now are, or hereafter shall, or may be giuen, payed, or allowed for the same, at Our Mint or Exchange.

Item, We will and declare, the Statute made in the eighteenth yeere of the reigne of the late Queene Elizabeth, Intituled, An Act for reformation of abuses in Goldsmiths, be put in due execution. And whereas by that Act, no Goldsmith ought to take for any Plate, Vessell, or worke of Gouldsmitherie of gould, aboue twelue pence the ounce, nor for place, Vessell, or worke of gouldsmitherie of siluer, aboue twelue pence the pound weight, or rateably besides the fashion, more then the buyer shall, or may be allowed for the same at the Kings exchange, or Mynt, which good and profitable Law hath not beene yet of any effect, by reason, that vpon euery such sale of gould, or siluer-plate, or other Gouldsmiths worke, there is no distinction made, or rate set of gould, or siluer apart, and of the fashion apart, whereby might appeare what the one, or the other was rated and prized at: To the ende to auoid this confusion, Wee doe will and Command, according to the rule and order of other States, That euery gouldsmith vpon euery sale of any gold, or siluer, or other worke of Gouldsmitherie, doe demand for, value, or rate apart, the gould, or siluer, and the fashion or workemanship apart. And vpon euery such sale, shall deliuer and giue vnto the buyer of any such place, or other worke of Gouldsmitherie demanding the same, a note, or ticket subseribed with his name, or marke, wherein shall be expressed, the day of the sale, and the weight of such plate, or vessell or other worke of Gouldsmitherie, of Gould or siluer sold, and the value or rate of gold and siluer apart, and the value and rate of fashion and workemanship apart, by which may appeare at what rate, the one or the other is valued or rated, wherby no frande or deceit can be made to the sayd Statute: And that the buyer, selling the same againe, may know, what to demaund for the same at the Kings Exchange or Mynt.

Item, To the end to auoyde and put to Our Coyne all Gold-money currant within this Our Realme being Clipped, Washed, or by any other meanes vnlawfully diminished, or lacking of the iust weight thereof, otherwise then according to the rates hereafter seuerally expressed, and with the also wance of the remedies set down in diuers former Proclamations of Queene Elizabeth, and of Our late Father of blessed memory, (that is to say) In euery peece of Gold currant for xxx.s. xx.s. xv.s. x.s. v.s. ii.s. vi.d. the remedie and abatement shall not exceede 4. Graines and a halfe, 3. Graines, 2. Graines and a halfe, 2. Graines, 1. Graine, halfe a Graine: All which remedies shal be allowed in euery peece accordingly, the same wanting no more being to passe, as if it were of full weight and iust value. But if any such peece of Coyne shall lacke of the true weight thereof aboue the remedies afore expressed, then We doe straitly charge and command, That no person or persons whatsoeuer shall accept or offer them in payment, vpon any allowance or defaulcation, for want of weight whatsoeuer, but that the same be, and stand by these presents decryed downe, and vncurrant. And that it shall be lawfull for euery person or persons, to whom offer of payment of any the sayd peeces lightned, as aforesayd, shall bee made, to braud the same, by striking a hole in euery of the sayd pieces so offered in payment, rendring those pieces so branded then presently afterwards to the owners thereof againe: which sayd lightned or branded pieces, Our pleasure is, shall be brought and carryed to Our Exchanges or Mint, there againe to bee molten and conuerted into Coyne.

Item, Forasmuch as it is impossible, but that the rates and prices of Gold and Siluer in Our Mint, or Exchanges will bee exceeded, and the same not to bee preuented, so long as way shall or may be giuen for the bringing in, selling or venting of any false, deceitfull or counterfeit Golde or Siluer, Plate, Vessel, Wier, spangles, Oaes Gold or Siluer threed, Lace, Rings, Spoones, Bodkins, or other Manufacturies, being not made, wrought, or sold according to the Standard of Our Mynt, or the Gold-smiths Hall, contrary to diuers Lawes and Proclamations heretofore enacted and published for redresse of the same; Wee doe therefore will and command, That no such false, deceitfull or counterfet Stuffe, or Manufacturie whatsoeuer, of Gold or Siluer, lesse in finenesse, or standard then Our Moneys of Gold or Siluer be made, wrought, vented, sold, or imported within, or into Our said Realme of England, or any other our Dominions.

Declaring neuertheles, that We doe not intend by Our said Proclamation, or any of these present Articles, to restraine any of Our Merchants importing Bullion from the parts beyong the Seas, orany other of Our subiects for any Gold or Siluer growing, or found within any of Our Realms or Dominions whatsoeuer, but that they, and euery of them shall stil be, and remaine at liberty to carry their said Bullion vnto Our sayd Exchange, or to Our Mynt, there to be molten into Our Coynes at their election; Any thing in these presents notwithstanding. And yet Our pleasure is, & We doe hereby straitly charge and command, That no Gold-smiths whatsoeuer, or other trading as a Gold-smith, shall, or doe by colour or pretence of being seruant or Factor to any such Merchant, or otherwise in the name of any such Merchant, buy, sell, or bring to Our Mynt, or otherwise intermeddle at all with any such Bullion, but after the sayd seuerall dayes before limited, shall bring, and carry the same vnto Our sayd Exchanger, his Deputies. Factors, or Seruants, there to be sold, and exchanged, according to the true intent of Our sayd Letters Patents, and Articles abouesayd; not intending neuerthelesse, but that the sayd Goldsmiths may vse their Trade of Goldsmithery as fully and amply, as heretofore they lawfully might or could doe: And that they & euery of them may vse & enioy the Franchises and liberties which they now lawfully haue & hold, by or from the Grants, or Charters of Vs, or any Our Predecessors, Kings of England, and may likewise exchange, or buy any Gold or Siluer, Plate, in Vessell, or other Manufactury of Gold or Siluer, as heretofore they lawfully might, or could, so that the same be bought or exchanged ouely to make Plate, or other worke of Goldsmithery, proper and belonging to their Trade, and be made and counerted into the same, and so as they doe not giue a rate, or price for the same, aboue the rate or price of Our Mynt; And likewise, that by colour or pretence hereof they doe not buy, exchange, or intermeddle at all with any Forreigne Species of Money, or other Bullion whatsoeuer, Imported, or comming from the parts beyond the Seas, or of the proper growth, or being found within any Our Realmes and Dominions: All which Our pleasure is, shall immediatly bee carryed, and brought vnto Our sayd Mynt, or Exchanges, to bee conuerted into Our Coyne, in augmentation and encrease thereof, for Our profit, and the good of Our Realme: Any prtence of practise, vsage, or custome herein made or had to the contrary in any wise notwithstanding.

Item, Our expresse Will and pleasure is, that the Premises, and euery Article thereof, be obserued and kept, not onely vpon paine and penaltie of such forfeitures and other punishments, as by any the Lawes or Statutes of this Our Realme, in such cases made and prouided, may bee inflicted vpon the offendors in the Premises, but likewise vpon penaltie of such fines and censures as by Our Court of Starre-chamber, may be inflicted vpon wilfull contemners of Our Royall Will and Command, grounded vpon the good and well-fare of Our Realme: to which purpose, Our wil & pleasure is, and We do hereby straitly charge and command Our Attourny General for the time being, to informe against such persons in Our Court of Star chamber from time to time, whose contempt and disobedience against this Our Royall Command, shall merit the censure of Our sayd Court, and to prosecute euery such Information, speedily, and effecually, vntill the same shal be brought to sentence:

Declaring neuerthelesse, that Wee doe not intend, or comprehend vnder any the Forfeitures, Penalties, or Censures aboue expressed, any such person or persons whatsoeuer, who committing or offending against any the premises with any other person, shall within fourty dayes next after his sayd offence, and delict perpetrated (so the same bee before any other person hath related and discouered his offence, or proceeded against him) discouer such other person or persons with whom he committed, or did the sayd offence, but for such his Information, relation, and discouery, shall be both freed of his owne Forfeitures, Penalties, and Censure aforesayd, as also enioy all such part of the Forfeiture of the said other party to the same offence, as amply as any other Informer or Relator, not hauing offended, might haue done, to whom, and to all other Discouerers, and such as will informe, concerning the premises, ouer and besides such part of the Forfeitures and Penalties allowed them by any the Statuies, or Actes of Parliament, made concerning the premises, such part of the Forfeitures accruing to Vs, as by Our said Commissioners shall be thought fit, shall be giuen and payd vnto them and euery of them, for their further reward for their discouery of any offence committed against all, or any of the premises.
